<item>Uruguay</item> <item>Venezuela</item> <item>French Guiana (France)</item> </map_countries_visible> <notes>Core stats list derived from the proof legend; exemplars/values derived ONLY from the XLSX 'Interesting Statistics' table.</notes> </continent_stats_map> <featurettes> <item> <featurette_id>featurette_1_lithium_triangle</featurette_id> <title>Powering the Future—South America's Lithium Triangle</title> <body_text>High in the sun-baked deserts where Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile meet, pale salt flats sparkle like mirrors. Beneath these dazzling plains lies something precious—lithium, a metal essential for the batteries that power our phones, cars, and even the future of clean energy. This region, known as the “Lithium Triangle,” holds more than half of the world’s known lithium reserves.
As electric vehicles and solar panels become common, the demand for lithium grows. Mining it can bring jobs and prosperity to local communities, yet it also raises tough questions. Extracting lithium uses lots of water and may affect nearby plants, animals, and indigenous peoples who have cared for this land for centuries. By working together— governments, businesses, and local communities—South America’s lithium-rich deserts can help shape a cleaner, greener tomorrow, without losing the natural and cultural treasures that make these places so special.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_1_lithium</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>sa_f1_photo_salt_flats</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>header_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>1.7777777777777777</aspect_ratio> <description>White salt flats under a bright blue sky (hero image for Lithium Triangle featurette).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1567693528052-e213227086bb?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&q=80&fm=jpg&crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&ixid=eyJhcHBfaWQiOjExNzczfQ&w=1600</final_url> <url_candidates> title transcribed from the proof poster.</notes> </item> <item> <featurette_id>featurette_2_languages</featurette_id> <title>One Continent, Two Languages— Spanish and Portuguese in South America</title> <body_text>If you look at a map of South America, you’ll find most countries speaking Spanish, while Brazil—the largest country—speaks Portuguese. This language divide began centuries ago when Spain and Portugal carved up new lands during the Age of Exploration. A special line called the Treaty of Tordesillas gave Portugal control of what is now Brazil, and Spain colonized much of the rest.
As a result, flavors of language, music, and dance flowed into these lands, mixing with the voices of indigenous peoples who have lived here for thousands of years. Today, from samba in Brazil to tango in Argentina, these traditions blend European words and rhythms with native sounds and stories. While Spanish and Portuguese dominate, hundreds of Indigenous languages still echo through rainforests and mountain villages, reminding us that South America’s true beauty lies in its rich tapestry of voices.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_2_languages</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>sa_f2_map_spanish_portuguese</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>supporting_map</role> <aspect_ratio>1.6</aspect_ratio> <description>Map showing where Spanish and Portuguese are spoken (Romance languages distribution reference).</description> <hyperlinks> Not visibly used on the proof poster, but included as a linked option in the Featurettes.docx.</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url>https://media.tacdn.com/media/attractions-splice-spp-674x446/06/96/6a/2a.jpg</final_url> <url_candidates> <item> <anchor_text>tango</anchor_text> <url>https://media.tacdn.com/media/attractions-splice-spp-674x446/06/96/6a/2a.jpg</url> <source_file>South America Featurettes.docx</source_file> <location>body.paragraph[15]</location> </item> </url_candidates> </hyperlinks> <status>not_on_proof_poster</status> </item> <item> <asset_id>sa_f2_illustration_romance_language_tree</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>illustration</role> <aspect_ratio>1.0</aspect_ratio> <description>Illustration: Romance languages family tree with Spanish and Portuguese as close relatives.</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url/> <url_candidates/> </hyperlinks> <chart_spec> <chart_type>illustrated_tree</chart_type> <layout_notes>Tree graphic titled 'ROMANCE LANGUAGES' with labeled branches (e.g., Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Vulgar Latin).</layout_notes> <data_table/> <iconization_rules/> </chart_spec> <notes>No explicit source URL found in provided docs for the tree illustration.</notes> </item> </assets> <data_source_links/> <notes>Body text and title transcribed from the proof poster.</notes> </item> <item> <featurette_id>featurette_3_food_trade</featurette_id> <title>Feeding the World —South America’s Role in Global Food Trade</title> <body_text>Have you ever tasted fresh grapes in winter, or savored coffee from far-off fields? South America is a food powerhouse, shipping fruits, grains, and coffee beans across oceans so that people everywhere can enjoy them all year long. Brazil’s coffee might end up in your morning cup, Chilean grapes could sweeten your afternoon snack, and Ecuadorian bananas may appear in your fruit bowl—even if it’s snowy outside your window.
This global trade supports farmers, builds roads and ports, and brings distant cultures closer together. But it also comes with challenges. Clearing forests for farmland may harm wildlife, and shipping food around the globe adds pollution. As more people demand these tasty treats, farmers, traders, and governments must find ways to grow crops sustainably, protect the environment, and ensure fair treatment for the hands that plant, harvest, and deliver our food tracing food from field to store.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_3_food_trade</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>sa_f3_photo_coffee_farm</asset_id> </chart_spec> </item> </assets> <data_source_links/> <notes>Body text and title transcribed from the proof poster.</notes> </item> <item> <featurette_id>featurette_4_tourism</featurette_id> <title>Tourism Transforming Communities —The Impact of Visitors</title> <body_text>From the ancient stone city of Machu Picchu perched high in Peru’s Andes to the thundering falls of Iguazu, South America’s wonders draw travelers from all over the world. These visitors bring money, helping pay for schools, hospitals, and better roads. They also learn about local traditions, celebrating colorful festivals and tasting foods that reflect centuries of culture.
But tourism can also bring problems. Too many people can wear down fragile ruins, disturb wildlife, or fill quiet towns with traffic and trash. Local residents must find a balance—welcoming guests while preserving the natural and cultural treasures that made these places special in the first place. By choosing sustainable tours, respecting local rules, and listening to the voices of community leaders, visitors can help ensure that tourism helps rather than harms, leaving a legacy that future generations can enjoy.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>slot_featurette_4_tourism</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>sa_f4_photo_machu_picchu</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>header_photo</role>
